factoid: Natásha was looking at Anatole and Anatole never removed his smiling eyes from Natásha's face, neck, and bare arms.
Natásha knew for certain that Anatole was enraptured by her.
Natásha was pleased that Anatole was enraptured by her.
Natásha felt constrained and oppressed by Anatole's presence.
When Natásha was not looking at Anatole, she felt that Anatole was looking at her shoulders.
Natásha involuntarily caught Anatole's eye so that Anatole should look into Natásha's eyes rather than elsewhere.
When Natásha looked into Anatole's eyes, she was frightened, realizing that there was no barrier of modesty between Natásha and other men.
Natásha did not know how it was that within five minutes she had come to feel herself terribly near to Anatole.
When Natásha turned away, she feared Anatole might seize her from behind by her bare arm and kiss her on the neck.
Natásha and Anatole spoke of most ordinary things.
Natásha felt that Natásha and Anatole were closer to one another than she had ever been to any man.
Natásha kept turning to Hélène and to Natásha's father, as if asking what it all meant.
Hélène was engaged in conversation with a general and did not answer Natásha's look.
Natásha's father's eyes said nothing but what they always said: "Having a good time? Well, I'm glad of it!"
During one of these moments of awkward silence, Anatole's prominent eyes were gazing calmly and fixedly at Natásha.
Natásha, to break the silence, asked Anatole how he liked Moscow.
Natásha asked the question and blushed.
Natásha felt all the time that by talking to Anatole she was doing something improper.
Anatole smiled as though to encourage Natásha.
Anatole said: "At first I did not like it much, because what makes a town pleasant ce sont les jolies femmes, isn’t that so? But now I like it very much indeed," looking at Natásha significantly.

Anatole said: "You'll come to the costume tournament, Countess? Do come!" and put out his hand to Natásha's bouquet and dropping his voice, he added, "You will be the prettiest there. Do come, dear countess, and give me this flower as a pledge!"
Natásha did not understand what Anatole was saying any more than Anatole understood himself.
Natásha felt that Anatole's incomprehensible words had an improper intention.
Natásha did not know what to say and turned away as if she had not heard Anatole's remark.
Natásha felt that Anatole was there behind her, so close behind her.
Natásha asked herself: "How is Anatole now? Confused? Angry? Ought I to put it right?" She could not refrain from turning round.
Natásha looked straight into Anatole's eyes, and Anatole's nearness, self-assurance, and the good-natured tenderness of his smile vanquished Natásha.
Natásha smiled just as Anatole was doing, gazing straight into Natásha's eyes.
Natásha again felt with horror that no barrier lay between Anatole and her.
The curtain rose again. Anatole left the box, serene and gay.
Natásha went back to Natásha's father in the other box, now quite submissive to the world she found herself in.

All that was going on before Natásha now seemed quite natural, but on the other hand all her previous thoughts of her betrothed, of Princess Mary, or of life in the country did not once recur to Natásha's mind and were as if belonging to a remote past.

In the fourth act there was some sort of devil who sang waving his arm about, till the boards were withdrawn from under him and he disappeared down below. That was the only part of the fourth act that Natásha saw.
Natásha felt agitated and tormented, and the cause of this was Kurágin whom Natásha could not help watching.
As Natásha and Anatole were leaving the theater, Anatole came up to them, called their carriage, and helped them in.
As Anatole was putting Natásha in, he pressed her arm above the elbow.
Agitated and flushed, Natásha turned round. Anatole was looking at Natásha with glittering eyes, smiling tenderly.

Only after Natásha had reached home was Natásha able clearly to think over what had happened to her, and suddenly remembering Prince Andrew she was horrified, and at tea to which all had sat down after the opera, Natásha gave a loud exclamation, flushed, and ran out of the room.
